Context:
* American Sign Language (ASL) is in high demand in Ontario due to the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA) introduced in 2005 that mandates accessibility standards for all levels of government and private and public sector businesses.
* Demand for ASL â€“ English interpreters exceeds the supply, creating opportunities for those trained.
* Interpreting work can take place anywhere clients need to go, including hospitals, banks, lawyer offices, conferences, and classes.
* Graduates are often self-employed and serve consumers of all ages.
* Knowledge of ASL and Deaf culture opens up doors for communication in any career and workplace.
* Partnerships with organizations embedded in the Deaf and deafblind communities provide field placement experiences, employment opportunities, and support ongoing development of programs.
* Contact Zeenat Janmohamed, Chair, School of Deaf and Deafblind Studies, for information on involvement.
* Apply to learn more about land acknowledgment and sign up for college news and updates.
* Phone number: 416-415-2000
* TTY number: 1-877-515-5559
* Email address: ask.george@georgebrown.ca
* Social Media Hub available for more information.
